required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Use of Ultrasound Guidance to Assist With Labor Epidural Placement in Patients With a BMI ≥40
clinical_study.official_title: Use of Ultrasound Guidance to Assist With Labor Epidural Placement in Patients With a BMI ≥40

brief_summary.textblock: Placement of labor epidurals is a very common daily practice in obstetrical anesthesia. Currently, these epidurals are placed based upon palpation of landmarks to determine midline and the correct spinal level for placement. Palpation of these landmarks can be difficult, however, particularly in morbidly obese patients who have significant amounts of soft tissue overlying them. This study seeks to use ultrasound guidance to examine the spine prior to epidural placement, and see what effects this has compared to palpation alone with respect to procedure time, number of attempts, success rate in the first attempt, failure rate, complication rate, patient anxiety levels, and patient satisfaction levels.

primary_outcome.measure: Total Time Required for Epidural Catheter Placement
primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed immediately during epidural catheter placement
primary_outcome.description: Includes the time required to evaluate the spine (via ultrasound or palpation) plus the time required to successfully place the epidural catheter

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed immediately during epidural catheter placement
secondary_outcome.description: Time required to successfully place the epidural catheter

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Attempts at Epidural Catheter Placement
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed immediately during epidural catheter placement

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Who Had Successful Placement of the Epidural Catheter in the First Attempt
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed immediately during epidural catheter placement
Assessed immediately during epidural catheter placement and within 24 hours after delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Any epidural related complication noted to occur including a failed epidural, inadvertent dural puncture, or paresthesia will be documented and reported.
Any epidural catheter that fails to provide appropriate analgesia requiring them to be replaced with a new epidural catheter will be documented and reported

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed immediately following epidural catheter placement
secondary_outcome.description: Immediately following epidural catheter placement, patients will be asked to rate their satisfaction level during the procedure on a 0-10 scale, with 0 being not at all satisfied, and 10 being extremely satisfied.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed immediately following epidural catheter placement
secondary_outcome.description: Immediately following epidural catheter placement, patients will be asked to rate their anxiety level during the procedure on a 0-10 scale, where 0 is no anxiety at all, and 10 is the worst anxiety imaginable.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed immediately prior to epidural catheter placement
secondary_outcome.description: The time taken to evaluate the spine, either by palpation or ultrasound guidance, and mark the location for epidural catheter insertion

Within 24 hours after delivery, patients will be given a 13 question survey. The survey is a modified Woman's Views of Birth Labor Satisfaction Questionnaire (WOMBLSQ) which asks patients to rate 13 various satisfaction related statements on a 1-7 scale, with 1 being totally disagree, 4 being neither agree nor disagree, and 7 being totally agree. Each of the 13 questions asked are designed to assess their overall satisfaction with their epidural catheter placement and overall anesthesia care. The total score is reported combining all 13 questions for a possible score range of 13-91. A higher total score indicates a higher overall anesthesia experience satisfaction level. No subscales were used.

arm_group.description: The interventional group that will have their spine evaluated by ultrasound prior to epidural placement
The control group that will have their epidural placed in the usual fashion based on palpation

intervention.description: Using ultrasound guidance to evaluate the spine prior to epidural placement
Using palpation only to evaluate the spine prior to epidural placement

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Current (pregnant) BMI ≥ 40
- Age ≥ 18
- ASA score of 3 or less
- Full term pregnancy (37 weeks gestational age or greater)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Known scoliosis
- Known contraindications to neuraxial blockade
- Intrauterine fetal demise or non-viable fetus.

group.description: Total of all reporting groups

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status
measure.description: ASA1, ASA2, and ASA3 are all categories that participants could fall into based on the status of their overall health. ASA1 indicates a normal, healthy patient. ASA2 indicates a patient with mild systemic disease (examples include but are not limited to pregnancy, current smoker, obesity with a BMI >30 but <40, and well controlled diabetes or hypertension). ASA3 indicates a patient with severe systemic disease (examples include but are not limited to poorly controlled diabetes or hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder, morbid obesity with a BMI greater than or equal to 40).

measure.title: External landmarks visible
measure.description: The back of the patient is visually examined to determine if the outline of the spinous processes of the vertebrae can be seen through the skin.

measure.title: Palpable interspace
measure.description: A patient has "palpable interspaces" when the spinous processes of the vertebrae, and thus the interspaces between them, can easily be physically felt by the provider through the patient's skin.
measure.population: Palpation was not performed in ultrasound group because only the ultrasound was used to asses location for epidural catheter placement in that group. The number of participants in the ultrasound group reflects only the number analyzed (i.e. 0) and the total number of participants analyzed reflects the total number analyzed (i.e. 9 participants).

outcome.title: Overall Anesthesia Experience Satisfaction
outcome.description: Within 24 hours after delivery, patients will be given a 13 question survey. The survey is a modified Woman's Views of Birth Labor Satisfaction Questionnaire (WOMBLSQ) which asks patients to rate 13 various satisfaction related statements on a 1-7 scale, with 1 being totally disagree, 4 being neither agree nor disagree, and 7 being totally agree. Each of the 13 questions asked are designed to assess their overall satisfaction with their epidural catheter placement and overall anesthesia care. The total score is reported combining all 13 questions for a possible score range of 13-91. A higher total score indicates a higher overall anesthesia experience satisfaction level. No subscales were used.

reported_events.time_frame: During the patients current hospitalization (typically 2-3 days)
reported_events.desc: All study participants were evaluated during and immediately following their epidural catheter procedure, and also later followed up on in person by study personnel within 24 hours of their delivery to assess for any adverse events

event.description: Number of participants sustaining an inadvertent dural puncture during the procedure resulting in the formation of a post-dural puncture headache
Number of patients experiencing a transient paresthesia in their back or leg(s) during epidural catheter placement

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
